subject: Re: [junit] How to test inner exception with @Rule
msgSnippet: Dave - you can use ExpectedException.expect(Matcher) [1] to supply a custom Hamcrest matcher that checks the inner exception of the exception. [1]
messageBody:
Dave -

you can use ExpectedException.expect(Matcher) [1] to supply a custom
Hamcrest matcher that checks the inner exception of the exception.

[1]
http://kentbeck.github.com/junit/javadoc/latest/org/junit/rules/ExpectedException.html#expect(org.hamcrest.Matcher
)

Best regards,

Marc

2011/2/23 banksysan <BanksySan@...>

>
> @Rule
> public ExpectedException thrown = ExpectedException.none();
>

> thrown.expect(MasterCatalogueBadMergeDataException.class);
> thrown.expectMessage(is(The field '" + fieldName + "' is not

>
> However, the exception contains an inner exception which I also want to
> check.
>
> Anyone know how I go about this?
>
> Thanks in advance
